method.name: add_pid
method.title: Makes an independent, temporary process known to the Job Scheduler

description.p: The Job Scheduler stops the process after the time limit has been exceeded.
This call is used to restrict the time allowed for processes that have been launched by a task. The Job Scheduler ends all independent processes still running at the end of a task.
A log entry is made each time the Job Scheduler stops a process. This does not affect the state of a task.
The method stops all processes for which the add_pid() method has been called.
A process group ID can be handed over on Unix systems as a negative pid. kill then stops the complete process group.
This time limit does not apply for processes being run on remote computers with .

property.name: error
property.title: Sets an error and stops the current job

description.p: This method call returns the last error which has occurred with the current task. Should no error have occurred, an object is returned, with the is_error property set to false.
An error message can also be written in the task log file using

The initial exit-code value is 0 - this is changed to 1 should an error occur. Note that an error is defined here as occurring when the Job Scheduler writes a line in the task log containing "[ERROR]":

The job can then set the
property - e.g. in the method.
The exit code resulting from an operating system process executing a task is not relevant here and, in contrast to jobs with or , is not automatically handed over to this property.
The exit code determines the commands to be subsequently carried out. See <job> for more information.
The exit codes have no influence for API jobs on whether or not a job is stopped (a task error message causes jobs to be stopped).

example.pre: spooler_log.error( "This call of spooler_log.error() sets the exit code to 1" ); spooler_task.exit_code = 0; // Reset the exit code
